item.title: Bird flu virus shows mutations in first severe human case in US: CDC - Business Standard
item.description:
Bird flu virus shows mutations in first severe human case in US: CDC

Last Updated: Dec 27 2024 | Source: Reuters

The United States reported its first severe case of bird flu, affecting a Louisiana resident over 65 years old, showing mutations not seen in previous infections.

  • The CDC confirmed the patient’s sample showed mutations in the hemagglutinin (HA) gene.
  • The risk to the general public remains low according to CDC's statement.
  • The patient was infected with the D1.1 genotype, distinct from the B3.13 genotype found in other cases.
  • Other countries have reported similar mutations, most often during severe cases.
  • No transmission from this patient to others has been found so far.
“The risk to the general public from the outbreak has not changed and remains low.”

This case highlights ongoing concerns about the mutations of the bird flu virus and its potential impact on public health.

item.title: Vigorous exercise vs. moderate intensity aerobics: Which one helps in faster weight loss? - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Vigorous Exercise vs. Moderate Intensity Aerobics: Which One Helps in Faster Weight Loss?

Date: Dec 27, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

A recent study led by Dr. Ahmad Jayedi has explored the effectiveness of vigorous exercise versus moderate-intensity aerobics on weight loss.

Key Points:

  • The study analyzed 116 clinical trials involving 6,880 participants.
  • Every 30 minutes of aerobic exercise weekly results in an average weight loss of 1.15 pounds.
  • Moderate-intensity exercise of 150 minutes per week can lead to a weight loss of 6.15 pounds.
  • Increasing moderate exercise to 300 minutes per week can boost weight loss to 9.24 pounds.
  • Vigorous exercise leads to faster fat loss but can also result in knee and ankle discomfort.

Notable Quotes:

“For decades, health experts have spoken about the benefits of regular exercise for weight loss. But how much exercise is good enough?”

Improvements in mental and physical health were also noted, but musculoskeletal symptoms emerged as a concern for participants engaging in vigorous exercise.

Disclaimer: This article is for informational purposes only and not a substitute for professional medical advice.

item.title: Why fatty liver cases rose in 2024: Wrong diet, no exercise and no sleep are bigger triggers than alcohol - The Indian Express
item.description:
Why Fatty Liver Cases Rose in 2024: The Role of Diet, Exercise, and Sleep

Publication Date: December 2024
Source: Indian Express

With India facing significant health issues related to obesity, diabetes, and heart disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is emerging as a serious new health threat. It occurs when fat accumulates in the liver of non-drinkers, causing inflammation and potential liver damage.

  • NAFLD affects almost one in three to four people in India.
  • The condition is increasingly recognized across all age groups.
  • Dr. SK Sarin emphasizes the importance of early detection through preventive guidelines prepared by the Health Ministry.
  • Fatty liver rates are becoming as prevalent as heart disease.
“Almost one in three to four people in India have fatty liver,” says Dr SK Sarin.

This rise in fatty liver cases underscores the importance of lifestyle changes to combat what may soon become a significant public health crisis.

item.title: Bird flu mutations found in first severe US human case, CDC reports - The Indian Express
item.description:
Bird flu mutations found in first severe US human case, CDC reports

Publication Date: December 14, 2024 | Source: Indian Express

The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced unusual genetic changes in the virus associated with the first severe human case of bird flu in the United States, confirming a case in a Louisiana resident.

  • The severe case was identified in a person over the age of 65 experiencing respiratory issues.
  • The D1.1 strain of the virus has been recently found in wild birds and poultry in the US.
  • The mutations affect the hemagglutinin (HA) gene, crucial for the virus's attachment to host cells.
  • The CDC reassured that the overall risk to the public remains low, with no evidence of person-to-person transmission.
  • Similar mutations have been observed in severe cases in other countries.
No evidence of the virus spreading from the Louisiana patient to others has been identified, the CDC added.

In conclusion, while the CDC is monitoring this rare case closely, it remains dedicated to ensuring public safety and awareness regarding bird flu.

item.title: Bird flu virus shows mutations in first severe human case in US, CDC says - ETHealthWorld
item.description:
Bird flu virus shows mutations in first severe human case in US, CDC says

Published On: Dec 27, 2024 at 06:22 AM IST Source: Reuters

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on the analysis of samples from the first severe case of bird flu in the country, revealing mutations in the hemagglutinin (HA) gene, which are not present in other infected birds.

  • First severe bird flu case reported in the US occurred in a Louisiana resident over 65 years old.
  • The CDC confirmed the mutations are rare but have been observed in other severe cases worldwide.
  • Risk to the general public remains low, according to the CDC.
No transmission from the Louisiana patient to others has been identified, said the CDC.

This case highlights potential changes in avian influenza that could affect public health monitoring and response strategies.

item.title: Bird flu virus shows mutations in first severe human case in US, CDC says - The Indian Express
item.description:
Bird Flu Virus Shows Mutations in First Severe Human Case in the US

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Indian Express

The US Centers for Disease Control reported the first severe case of bird flu in Louisiana, indicating new mutations of the virus that have not been previously identified in local flocks.

  • The patient, over the age of 65, suffered from severe respiratory illness.
  • Mutations were found in the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of the virus.
  • The D1.1 genotype was confirmed, distinct from others found in the US.
  • No person-to-person transmission has been reported.
  • The overall risk to the public remains low.
No transmission from the patient in Louisiana to other persons has been identified, said the CDC.

The emergence of these mutations is concerning but should not prompt immediate panic as the risk to the general population is still deemed low.

item.title: Forget 10,000 Steps A Day, New Study Reveals How Much Walking Is Actually Enough - News18
item.description:
Forget 10,000 Steps A Day, New Study Reveals How Much Walking Is Actually Enough

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: News18

A recent study suggests that walking 7,500 steps daily can significantly benefit mental health by reducing the risk of depression without the need to meet the often-quoted 10,000 steps goal.

  • A study published in JAMA Network Open found that exceeding 7,500 steps does not provide additional health benefits.
  • Walking 7,500 steps can lower depression risk by up to 42%.
  • Even modest physical activity can significantly enhance health outcomes.
  • Dr. Lindsay Bottoms and Professor Tom Yates emphasize the arbitrary nature of the 10,000-step goal and recommend more realistic walking goals.
  • Research indicates that as few as 4,400 steps can improve life expectancy.
“The 10,000-step goal is arbitrary and can give a misleading sense of health security.” – Dr. Lindsay Bottoms

In conclusion, setting achievable walking goals is crucial for maintaining health without unnecessary stress, with significant benefits observable even with fewer than the often recommended 10,000 steps.

item.title: 5 Reasons Why Evening Walks In Winter Are Great For Your Health, As Per Doctor - HerZindagi English
item.description:
5 Reasons Why Evening Walks In Winter Are Great For Your Health, As Per Doctor

Publication Date: Not Specified

Source: HerZindagi

Evening walks during winter not only provide therapeutic benefits but also numerous health advantages. Expert Dr. Indramani Upadhyay outlines how these walks are particularly beneficial in the colder months.

  • Boosts Immunity: Regular evening walks strengthen the immune system and help fight off illnesses.
  • Improves Mood And Reduces Stress: Walking can help reduce stress and counteract seasonal affective disorder.
  • Enhances Cardiovascular Health: Walking improves heart health and reduces the risk of heart disease.
  • Supports Weight Management: Evening walks help maintain a healthy weight and boost metabolism.
  • Strengthens Bones And Joints: Walking is a weight-bearing exercise that helps strengthen bones and prevent stiffness.
Dr. Indramani said, “Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) and winter blues are common during the colder months due to reduced sunlight exposure.”

To make winter walks safe and enjoyable, Dr. Upadhyay advises dressing in layers, wearing proper footwear, staying visible, and staying hydrated.

item.description:
Weight Loss Diets that were all the rage in 2024

Published on: Unknown Source: Times of India

“The new diets are not just about losing weight but also enhancing overall health and wellness.”

In conclusion, the article emphasizes the importance of choosing a diet that not only helps in weight loss but also promotes a healthy lifestyle.

item.title: Study Links Seed Oils To Increased Cancer Risk: Everything You Need To Know - News18
item.description:
Study Links Seed Oils To Increased Cancer Risk: Everything You Need To Know

Last Updated: December 26, 2024, 19:57 IST

A study has shed light on a troubling connection between popular cooking oils and the increasing incidence of cancer, especially in younger individuals. The research, published in the medical journal Gut, reveals that frequent consumption of seed oils such as sunflower, grapeseed, canola, and corn oil may heighten cancer risk, raising serious concerns about health hazards linked to the overuse of these oils.

Key discoveries from the study

  • Examined 80 colon cancer patients and found elevated levels of bioactive lipids.
  • Analysis of 81 tumor samples showed a strong presence of lipids linked to seed oil consumption.
  • Seed oils have a history of promoting inflammation and are linked to chronic conditions.
  • Highlighted the role of chronic inflammation in cancer growth.
  • Introduced the emerging field of resolution medicine to counteract persistent inflammation.

Notable Quotes or Statistics

The study highlights the role of chronic inflammation caused by the overconsumption of seed oils, which has been shown to contribute to the growth and spread of cancer.

In summary, this study opens new avenues for understanding the links between dietary habits and cancer risk, emphasizing the need for cautious consumption of seed oils.

item.title: COVID-19 infection not linked to changes in MS symptom severity - Medical Xpress
item.description:
COVID-19 infection not linked to changes in MS symptom severity

Publication Date: December 23, 2024 Source: Neurology

COVID-19 infection is not associated with immediate changes in multiple sclerosis (MS) symptom severity or disability, according to a study published online.

  • The study examined 796 participants with COVID-19 infections and 1,336 uninfected individuals.
  • Findings indicated that MS symptoms and disability did not significantly differ between cohorts.
  • The immediate effect of COVID-19 on MS symptom severity was minimal.
"These findings enhance our general understanding of the consequences of infection in people with MS and are reassuring regarding the impact of COVID-19 on the course of MS," the authors write.

In conclusion, the study reassures that COVID-19 does not significantly impact the symptoms or disability of patients with multiple sclerosis.

item.title: Breakthrough sunscreen protects and cools your skin simultaneously: All you want to know - The Times of India
item.description:
Breakthrough sunscreen protects and cools your skin simultaneously: All you want to know

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

This article discusses a new sunscreen innovation that provides protection while also cooling the skin. It highlights the unique properties and benefits of the product.

  • The sunscreen offers enhanced protection against UV rays.
  • It incorporates cooling technology for comfort during wear.
  • The product aims to address common sunscreen complaints such as greasiness and irritation.
"This sunscreen not only shields your skin but also provides an instant cooling effect, making it perfect for hot days."

This new sunscreen could revolutionize the way consumers approach sun protection, making it a more pleasant experience.

item.title: A global polio resurgence and the need to reevaluate the basics - The Hindu
item.description:
A Global Polio Resurgence and the Need to Reevaluate Our Approach

Published on: December 26, 2024 10:48 pm IST

Source: Unknown

The article discusses the recent resurgence of polio worldwide, emphasizing the critical need for vigilant vaccination and monitoring. The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported environmental samples of poliovirus detected in several European countries, indicating an ongoing risk.

  • The resurgence includes cases in Pakistan, Cameroon, and Nigeria, with ongoing vaccine-derived poliovirus circulation.
  • WHO emphasizes the importance of vaccination to prevent paralysis and death from poliovirus.
  • A recent debate on the best vaccination approach—the replacement of the oral polio vaccine (OPV) with the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV)—is highlighted.
  • Research suggests respiratory transmission may play a more significant role than previously acknowledged.
“Vaccination of every vulnerable child is essential to ensure that the virus cannot lead to lifelong paralysis or even death.” - Robb Butler, Director, Communicable Diseases, Environment and Health at WHO/Europe.

This global health challenge underscores the need for immediate action in vaccination strategies to safeguard future generations against polio.

item.title: Which infectious disease is likely to be biggest emerging problem in 2025? - The Indian Express
item.description:
Which infectious disease is likely to be biggest emerging problem in 2025?

Publication Date: N/A | Source: Indian Express

The article discusses concerns among public health officials regarding emerging infectious diseases, particularly as COVID-19 recedes. It highlights the potential threat posed by the H5N1 influenza virus and compares it with ongoing threats such as malaria, HIV, and tuberculosis.

  • COVID-19 has raised awareness of the potential for new infectious diseases.
  • Malaria, HIV, and tuberculosis currently kill around 2 million people annually.
  • H5N1 bird flu is spreading among birds and recently infecting cattle in the US.
  • There has been a significant increase in human bird flu cases in 2023.
  • H5N1 has a high mortality rate in humans but does not currently spread between people.
  • A mutation could potentially enable human-to-human transmission of H5N1.
  • Governments are preparing for the possibility of a pandemic by acquiring vaccines and planning responses.
If this strain of bird flu makes that switch and can start transmitting between humans, governments must act quickly to control the spread.

The article concludes that while H5N1 poses a potential threat, existing diseases must also be prioritized in public health initiatives.

item.title: COVID-19 Infection Not Linked to Changes in MS Symptom Severity - HealthDay
item.description:
COVID-19 Infection Not Linked to Changes in MS Symptom Severity

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: HealthDay News

COVID-19 infection is not associated with immediate changes in multiple sclerosis (MS) symptom severity or disability, according to a study published online Dec. 23 in Neurology.

Key Points:

  • The study examined the effects of COVID-19 on MS symptoms using the SymptoMScreen (SMSS).
  • Involved 796 COVID-19 infected participants and 1,336 uninfected participants.
  • Findings showed no significant difference in SMSS scores between the cohorts before or after COVID-19 infection.
"These findings enhance our general understanding of the consequences of infection in people with MS and are reassuring regarding the impact of COVID-19 on the course of MS," the authors write.

Overall, the study provides reassurance that COVID-19 does not worsen MS symptom severity or lead to increased disability in affected individuals.

item.title: Atogepant Superior for Efficacy, Functional Measures in Migraine - HealthDay
item.description:
Atogepant Superior for Efficacy, Functional Measures in Migraine

Date: December 26, 2024 Source: HealthDay News

The recent study published in Neurology highlights that atogepant 60 mg once daily demonstrates greater efficacy and improved functional measures for adults suffering from migraine compared to placebo.

  • Atogepant significantly reduced the number of migraine days in various studies.
  • Results showed better efficacy in trials ADVANCE, ELEVATE, and PROGRESS.
  • Published results indicate improved quality of life scores for patients using atogepant.
  • The study addresses an important need for effective preventive treatments in migraine management.
"The analyses reported here demonstrate the early efficacy and functional improvements of atogepant and address a key unmet need of providing preventive treatment options with early benefits across the spectrum of migraine disease state severity." - Richard B. Lipton, M.D.

The findings underscore the potential of atogepant as a promising option for migraine sufferers, providing hope for earlier intervention and improved quality of life.

item.title: Nile rats and Black Death: Mummy reveals bubonic plague in Egypt 3,290 years ago - The Jerusalem Post
item.description:
Nile rats and Black Death: Mummy reveals bubonic plague in Egypt 3,290 years ago

Publication Date: December 26, 2024

Source: The Jerusalem Post

Researchers have uncovered the oldest confirmed case of the plague outside Eurasia in an ancient Egyptian mummy, suggesting that the deadly disease was present in North Africa thousands of years before the Black Death devastated Europe.

  • The mummy revealed traces of Yersinia pestis DNA.
  • Radiocarbon dating places the mummy at approximately 3,290 years ago.
  • Findings support the theory that bubonic plague circulated in North Africa long before the Middle Ages.
  • Symptoms described in ancient texts correlate with plague characteristics.
  • Studies indicate that Yersinia pestis existed globally thousands of years prior to known pandemics.
The bubonic plague was responsible for the deaths of more than 20 million people in Europe alone.

The presence of plague DNA in the mummy indicates that the individual suffered severe symptoms before death, raising questions about whether this was an isolated case or part of a broader epidemic.
